definition:
A structured set $S$ (typically a filter or a Boolean algebra) is
$\kappa$-complete if, given any $K\subseteq S$ with $|K|<\kappa$,
$\bigcap K\in S$. It is *complete* if it is $\kappa$-complete for all
$\kappa$.

Similarly, a partial order is $\kappa$-complete if any sequence of fewer
than $\kappa$ elements has an upper bound within the partial order.

A $\aleph_1$-complete is called *countably complete*.
